subject: Re: Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()

messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
> On Tue, May 19, 2009 at 11:13 AM, Pigneri, Rocco <rpigneri@...> wrote:
> > This idea stands well on its own merits, and the notation does have some
> > obvious benefits over the Hamcrest notation.  However, I have one
> > burning question: why not continue to improve Hamcrest?  While the
> > notation is not stellar, it does get the job done and seems to have all
> > the relevant error reporting implemented.
>
> It's not a matter of notation: it's the requirement to create,
> remember, and statically import a new matcher for every boolean
> expression.

The advantage Hamcrest's matcher factory functions is that the assertThat method is seamlessly extensible by the user. I can write assertThat(someString, isMyMothersMaidenName()), for example, and it looks no different, stylistically, to assertThat(someString, containsString("foo")). The user can write one small component -- the new matcher -- and seamlessly plug it into anything that accepts a matcher and get all the testing and diagnostic descriptions almost for free.

David's suggestion is convenient but cannot be extended. I can't write assertThat(someString).isMyMothersMaidenName(), for example. I'd like to see some middle-ground between the two. Maybe a factory function can use reflection to create a matcher that is then passed as a parameter to assertThat. I think this is how the logicalpractice-collections library works.

--Nat
